heisig_chinese_memo: A magic wand mysteriously standing above the floor all by itself.
heisig_constituent: above, magic wand, augury, divining rod, one, floor
heisig_story: The two directions, above and below, are usually pointed at with the finger. But the characters do not follow that custom, so we have to choose something else, easily remembered. The primitives show a magic wand standing above a floor - "magically," you might say. Anyway, go right on to the next frame, since the two belong together and are best remembered as a unit, just as the words above and below suggest each other.

WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: You find a toe on the ground. It's weird, because it's above the ground, not where toes belong.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Focus your imagination on how body parts should be buried, not above ground like this. Sure, finding a toe is a little strange, but finding a toe above the ground? Downright silly.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: Of course when you find a toe above the ground, you want to know where the toe came from. When you examine it, you see a name written on there. This toe belongs to the local clumsy farmhand, Jourm („Åò„Çá„ÅÜ).
WaniKani_Reading_Info:
Try to remember Jourm, the local farmhand. He is a recurring character that will come up anytime the reading for a kanji is „Åò„Çá„ÅÜ.
He is a very big man, and he wears farmer's clothes. It's important to imagine your version of Jourm as very big, because it will help us to differentiate him from Jo-Anne, who is the character associated with the similar, but shorter reading (and character) „Åò„Çá. Although Jourm will develop as you go through all the „Åò„Çá„ÅÜ reading kanji, for now just imagine him as a big, kinda slow dude who works for a local farmer. Also, he only has nine or fewer toes, apparently.
chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: A magic wand mysteriously standing above the floor all by itself.
origin_of_ch_char_book: Tortoise Plastron with Divination Inscription (Jia) and Scapula Bone with Inscription (Gu) (16th-11th century BC) Kings or shamans believed they could consult the gods, through fortune telling, about all affairs of the state, and so they sought guidance regarding political and military events, economics and ceremonial needs. These writings tell the results of the fortune or prophecies told by gods. The most important of the gods was Shang Di (‰∏äÂ∏ù), the god of Heaven. Sculpture of a Shang Dynasty Man (13th century-11th century BC)

Meaning Mnemonic
You find a toe on the ground. It's weird, because it's above the ground, not where toes belong.
Focus your imagination on how body parts should be buried, not above ground like this. Sure, finding a toe is a little strange, but finding a toe above the ground? Downright silly.
Reading Mnemonic
Of course when you find a toe above the ground, you want to know where the toe came from. When you examine it, you see a name written on there. This toe belongs to the local clumsy farmhand, Jourm („Åò„Çá„ÅÜ).
Try to remember Jourm, the local farmhand. He is a recurring character that will come up anytime the reading for a kanji is „Åò„Çá„ÅÜ.
He is a very big man, and he wears farmer's clothes. It's important to imagine your version of Jourm as very big, because it will help us to differentiate him from Jo-Anne, who is the character associated with the similar, but shorter reading (and character) „Åò„Çá. Although Jourm will develop as you go through all the „Åò„Çá„ÅÜ reading kanji, for now just imagine him as a big, kinda slow dude who works for a local farmer.
